name: Thai Glass Noodle Soup
description: A comforting-yet-light soup with a flavourful rich broth. This classic Thai recipe is a kid-friendly soup that's beloved by adults as well. Glass noodles, napa cabbage and egg tofu can all be subbed out for whatever you'd like!

video.name: Thai Glass Noodle Soup with Egg Tofu
video.description: This comforting soup is the epitome of simple Thai home cooking. It's a soup that just about every Thai family makes regularly, mine included, and especially if they have kids. It's called gaeng jued which literally means "bland curry," but it is anything but bland!

recipeIngredient: 12 oz Chinese-style chopped pork spare ribs or chicken wings drumettes (see note 2)
1  2-inch section daikon or ¼ onion (peeled and large-diced (optional))
4 cups 160 g napa cabbage, bite-sized pieces
Fried garlic and garlic oil for topping (optional but highly recommended, recipe below)
½ lb ground pork or chicken (preferably not lean)
Few cracks of freshly ground white pepper

recipeInstructions.text: If you’re using pork ribs, go through them to find ones that are meaty, and cut them down so the meaty part isn’t more than about ½-inch thick. This is just to speed up the cooking; you can leave them chunky if you have time to let them cook longer.
recipeInstructions.name: If you’re using pork ribs, go through them to find ones that are meaty, and cut them down so the meaty part isn’t more than about ½-inch thick. This is just to speed up the cooking; you can leave them chunky if you have time to let them cook longer.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the ribs or the wings to a pot, cover with water and season with fish sauce, soy sauce, sugar, and white pepper. Let that simmer for 5-10 minutes, just until you see a bunch of foam gathered on top, and then skim it off.
recipeInstructions.name: Add the ribs or the wings to a pot, cover with water and season with fish sauce, soy sauce, sugar, and white pepper. Let that simmer for 5-10 minutes, just until you see a bunch of foam gathered on top, and then skim it off.

recipeInstructions.text: Add cilantro stems and daikon and loosely cover the pot so it doesn’t reduce too much. Let this simmer until the meat is fork tender, wings will take a total of 20 mins, and the ribs 30-40 mins depending on the size.
recipeInstructions.name: Add cilantro stems and daikon and loosely cover the pot so it doesn’t reduce too much. Let this simmer until the meat is fork tender, wings will take a total of 20 mins, and the ribs 30-40 mins depending on the size.

recipeInstructions.text: Meanwhile soak the glass noodles in room temp water for at least 7 minutes to soften, then drain and cut into 2-3 sections. (If you want to add fried garlic, now would be a good time to make it, recipe below.)

recipeInstructions.text: Make the meatballs by combining all ingredients together and use your hand to knead the mixture until well combined.
recipeInstructions.name: Make the meatballs by combining all ingredients together and use your hand to knead the mixture until well combined.

recipeInstructions.text: Once the ribs/wings are done simmering, use 2 spoons to scoop and flick bite-sized chunks of meatballs into the soup.
recipeInstructions.name: Once the ribs/wings are done simmering, use 2 spoons to scoop and flick bite-sized chunks of meatballs into the soup.

recipeInstructions.text: After the meatballs are all added, allow the soup to come back to a boil if it has stopped, and then add the napa cabbage and egg tofu, then wait for the soup to come back to a boil. Then add the glass noodles and cook for 3 mins.
recipeInstructions.name: After the meatballs are all added, allow the soup to come back to a boil if it has stopped, and then add the napa cabbage and egg tofu, then wait for the soup to come back to a boil. Then add the glass noodles and cook for 3 mins.

recipeInstructions.text: Taste and adjust seasoning with more soy sauce or fish sauce as needed, then finish it off with green onions and/or cilantro. Top with fried garlic to finish. This soup is typically served with rice, but if you want to eat it by itself, that's fine too!

For the Fried Garlic and Garlic Oil

itemListElement.text: Chop the garlic just until the pieces are no bigger than ⅛-inch, but don't mince it finely.
itemListElement.name: Chop the garlic just until the pieces are no bigger than ⅛-inch, but don't mince it finely.

itemListElement.text: Add the oil to a small pot, then put one piece of garlic in it and turn the heat to medium. Once the piece of garlic is bubbling, add the rest of the garlic then turn the heat down to medium low.
itemListElement.name: Add the oil to a small pot, then put one piece of garlic in it and turn the heat to medium. Once the piece of garlic is bubbling, add the rest of the garlic then turn the heat down to medium low.

itemListElement.text: Stir the garlic until the pieces are a light golden (not brown!) and the bubbling has mostly subsided. Off the heat and drain using a metal sieve. Keep the garlic and the garlic oil in separate air-tight containers, and store them in the fridge.

review.reviewBody: I've been making this 2-3 times a month, and it's become a staple in my family. It's so comforting to eat. Thanks!

Hi - this was a recommended video for me on YouTube and I just happened to have some pork stock in the fridge along with pork mince - made this with pork meatballs plus a few wontons, added a little bit of ginger as well just because it was there. The soup is incredible! Thank you for a recipe that I otherwise would have gone my whole life without knowing! Delicious!
I love this recipe!!  Thanks for posting it for us.
This soup is so warm and comforting. My first time cooking with pork spare ribs and it turned out so great.
Easy and delicious, I’ve made the version in the pork stock video before, but this one? I could make the stock in one go, even easier.

Easy and adaptable. Add what you like, add what you have on hand. I feel like when I make it it's never the same each time, and that is one of the things I like about it. I could stick to the same exact recipe every time but it is good to use up what you have handy. Very healthy and very pocketbook friendly, easily customizable, all things that make this a winner!
I make variations of this dish all the time. I never knew what it was called.
